image.altText: a skyline with houses

items.synopsis: Interest rates climb above 4 per cent for the first time in more than 11 years, as the Reserve Bank moves aggressively to clamp down on inflation.

title.children: Cash rate surges past 4 per cent as RBA hikes again

image.altText: Business people walk outside the Reserve Bank of Australia.

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank has increased the cash rate to 4.1 per cent at its June meeting, citing "persistent" and "ongoing" high inflation. It's the highest cash rate since April 2012. Follow live.

title.children: Reserve Bank lifts cash rate to 4.1pc, but won't rule out 'further tightening' to tackle inflation

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe again sounded a warning about the rising cost of services, such as hospitality, which are labour intensive and vulnerable to rising wages. "Recent data indicate that the upside risks to the inflation outlook have increased and the board has responded to this," he noted in his post-meeting statement. "While goods price inflation is slowing, services price inflation is still very high and is proving to be very persistent overseas. Unit labour costs are also rising briskly, with productivity growth remaining subdued." In particular, Mr Lowe drew attention to last week's slightly bigger than expected rise in minimum and award wages, which was the highest in decades. "Wages growth has picked up in response to the tight labour market and high inflation," he observed. "Growth in public sector wages is expected to pick up further and the annual increase in award wages was higher than it was last year. "At the aggregate level, wages growth is still consistent with the inflation target, provided that productivity growth picks up." In contrast â€” Treasurer Jim Chalmers has pointed out that the rate rise is because of inflation, not the higher wages announced by the Fair Work Commission last week. (Hmm, that sounds like a good question for Gareth to me...)
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What has Philip Lowe said about the rate rise?

children.content: Reserve Bank governor Philip Lowe again sounded a warning about the rising cost of services, such as hospitality, which are labour intensive and vulnerable to rising wages.
"Recent data indicate that the upside risks to the inflation outlook have increased and the board has responded to this," he noted in his post-meeting statement.

"While goods price inflation is slowing, services price inflation is still very high and is proving to be very persistent overseas. Unit labour costs are also rising briskly, with productivity growth remaining subdued."
In particular, Mr Lowe drew attention to last week's
Â
slightly bigger than expected rise in
Â
minimum and award wages
, which was the highest in decades.
"Wages growth has picked up in response to the tight labour market and high inflation," he observed.
"Growth in public sector wages is expected to pick up further and the annual increase in award wages was higher than it was last year.
"At the aggregate level, wages growth is still consistent with the inflation target, provided that productivity growth picks up."
In contrast â€” Treasurer Jim Chalmers has pointed out that the rate rise is because of inflation, not the higher wages announced by the Fair Work Commission last week.
(Hmm, that sounds like a good question for Gareth to me...)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is speaking in Canberra now in response to the RBA's rate rise. He's reiterated the point made by RBA governor Philip Lowe at Senate Estimates last week, who said the federal budget was not increasing inflation in the economy. Here's some of what he had to say: "This rate rise today is not because of the budget and not because people on the minimum wage are being paid too much," he said. "This rate rise is because inflation is more persistent in the economy than any of us would like. "We have acted decisively in the budget to address cost of living pressures ... the RBA governor made it clear that he budget is taking pressure off inflation. "This is a difficult day for Australians."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer: 'This is a difficult day for Australians'

children.content: Treasurer Jim Chalmers is speaking in Canberra now in response to the RBA's rate rise.
He's reiterated the point made by RBA governor Philip Lowe at Senate Estimates last week, who said the federal budget was not increasing inflation in the economy.
Here's some of what he had to say:
"This rate rise today is not because of the budget and not because people on the minimum wage are being paid too much," he said.
"This rate rise is because inflation is more persistent in the economy than any of us would like.
"We have acted decisively in the budget to address cost of living pressures ... the RBA governor made it clear that he budget is taking pressure off inflation.
"This is a difficult day for Australians."
